```{r}
#1.
shoe_size <- c(6.5, 9.0, 8.5, 8.5, 10.5, 7.0, 9.5, 9.0, 13.0, 7.5, 10.5, 8.5, 12.0, 10.5, 13.0, 11.5, 8.5, 5.0, 10.0, 6.5, 7.5, 8.5, 10.5, 8.5, 10.5, 11.0, 9.0, 13.0)

height <- c(66.0, 68.0, 64.5, 65.0, 70.0, 64.0, 70.0, 71.0, 72.0, 64.0,
            74.5, 67.0, 71.0, 71.0, 77.0, 72.0, 59.0, 62.0, 72.0, 66.0,
            64.0, 67.0, 73.0, 69.0, 72.0, 70.0, 69.0, 70.0)
gender <- c("F", "F", "F", "F", "M", "F", "F", "F", "M", "F", 
            "M", "F", "M", "M", "M", "M", "F", "F", "M", "F", 
            "F", "M", "M", "F", "M", "M", "M", "M")
household_data <- data.frame(Shoe_size = shoe_size, Height = height, Gender = gender)

household_data
#a. The dataset contains 28 entries with shoe sizes ranging from 5.0 to 13.0, heights from 59.0 to 77.0 inches, and a mix of male and female individuals.
```
```{r}
#b. 
male_data <- subset(household_data, Gender == "M")
female_data <- subset(household_data, Gender == "F")

male_data
female_data
```
```{r}
#c.
mean(shoe_size)
mean(height)
```
```{r}
#d. Mostly yes, shoe sizes are shown to correlate according to height; the taller they are the bigger the size. However, there are exceptions.
```
```{r}
#2.
months <- c("March","April","January","November","January",
"September","October","September","November","August", "January","November","November","February","May","August", "July","December","August","August","September","November","February",
"April")
factor_months_vector <- factor(months)
factor_months_vector
```
```{r}
#3.
summary(months)
summary(factor_months_vector)
#They are both useful as the summary for months shows the length, class, and mode of the data, while the summary for factor_months_vector shows how many times each month is present.
```
